stem: An 84-year-old client with a history of malabsorption syndrome is admitted with new-onset PVCs and anorexia. He takes Digoxin for chronic AFib. Based on the documentation in the Critical Micro-Nutrient & Rhythm Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition and the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Increased frequency of arrhythmias in a chronic Dig patient.
Background: Chronic Digoxin 0.125mg. History of Celiac disease.
Assessment: Client is reporting nausea and 'heart skipping.'
Recommendation: Panel for magnesium and potassium.

tabs.title: Micro-Nutrient & Rhythm Log
tabs.content:
TestResultInterpretation
Serum Magnesium (Mg++)1.2 mg/dL (Low)Hypomagnesemia
Serum Digoxin1.8 ng/mLHigh-Normal (Borderline)
Serum Potassium (K+)3.6 mEq/LLow-Normal
CardiogramFrequent Multifocal PVCsEctopy

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 112/68, HR 92 (Irregular), RR 18. Client is pale.

conditionOptions.text: Stable Heart Failure with expected Ectopy

actionOptions.text: Hold the next dose of Digoxin
Administer IV Magnesium Sulfate as prescribed
Encourage the client to eat high-potassium bananas only
Increase the Digoxin dose to 0.25mg to suppress the PVCs

parameterOptions.text: Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Hypomagnesemia-Potentiated Digoxin Toxicity (c2). Magnesium is a 'calming' ion for the heart; when it is low (1.2), the heart becomes hypersensitive to Digoxin's effects, even if the Digoxin level itself is 'Normal' (1.8). The nausea and multifocal PVCs are the toxic indicators. The nurse should hold the next Digoxin dose (a1) and fix the Magnesium (a2). Key parameters include tracking both Mg++ and K+ (p1) and monitoring for lethal cardiac transitions (p2).
clinicalPearls: Hypomagnesemia often co-exists with hypokalemia and effectively 'unmasks' digoxin toxicity.
In malabsorption (Celiac/Crohn's), magnesium is the first electrolyte to drop.
PVCs in a Digoxin patient should always be treated as 'Toxicity until proven otherwise.'

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the Digoxin is fine because the level is 1.8 (under 2.0).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NCLEX logic uses 'Clinical Presentation' over 'Lab Numbers.' If the patient has the classic signs (nausea, skips) and an electrolyte imbalance, it is toxicity, regardless of a 'normal' lab value.

mnemonic.title: Low Mag-Bad Dig
mnemonic.expansion: Low Mag = Heart is Mad. Digoxin gets mean, even at 1.8.
